dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The EU's new 750 billion euro Recovery and Resilience Facility, it's a massive step toward joint debt.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The E U's new seven hundred fifty billion euro Recovery and Resilience Facility, it's a massive step toward joint debt.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and they're really emphasizing that, um, these funds have to actually deliver results, not scandals.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and they're really emphasizing that, um, these funds have to actually deliver results, not scandals.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In short, Europeans expect results, not scandals.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. The text mentions the tragic case of Ján Kuciak in Slovakia, murdered over his investigation into EU fund misuse—it's a stark reminder of the risks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. The text mentions the tragic case of Ján Kuciak in Slovakia, murdered over his investigation into E U fund misuse-it's a stark reminder of the risks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2018, a series of investigations tied the murders of journalist Ján Kuciak and his fiancée Martina Kušnírová to his investigation into the misuse of EU funds in Slovakia.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and then there was that scandal in Bulgaria where ministers resigned after embezzling agricultural funds. It's not just theoretical.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and then there was that scandal in Bulgaria where ministers resigned after embezzling agricultural funds. It's not just theoretical.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The following year, several ministers in Bulgarias government stepped down after revelations that they had embezzled EU agricultural funds to acquire real estate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Hungary example too—1.8 billion euros in a transport project with serious irregularities, even involving the prime minister's family.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Hungary example toominus one point eight billion euros in a transport project with serious irregularities, even involving the prime minister's family.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In Hungary, the EUs anti-fraud office uncovered serious irregularities in a 1.7 billion ($2 billion) transport project and in contracts negotiated with the prime ministers son-in-law to provide street lighting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So the oversight bodies like the European Anti-Fraud Office are supposed to prevent all this, but their resources are stretched thin.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the oversight bodies like the European Anti-Fraud Office are supposed to prevent all this, but their resources are stretched thin.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The EU is spending more money than ever, but the institutions needed to maintain the credibility of its expenditures are underfunded.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, I mean, uh, each staff member now has to monitor 910 million euros worth of spending? Back in 2011 it was only 310 million.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, I mean, uh, each staff member now has to monitor nine hundred ten million euros worth of spending? Back in twenty eleven it was only three hundred ten million.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For example, in the latest EU budget proposal, the European Commission assumes that each staff member in the anti-fraud office will monitor 900 million worth of EU expenditures. In 2010, that same staff member would have been responsible for scrutinizing 300 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And their staffing dropped from 470 to 380 employees, even though the budget's more than doubled. That's just unsustainable.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And their staffing dropped from four hundred seventy to three hundred eighty employees, even though the budget's more than doubled. That's just unsustainable.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2010, the office had 466 employees; this year, that number is 376, even though the money that needs supervising has more than doubled.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's a dangerous combo—more money than ever, but less oversight. No wonder Renew Europe pushed for budget amendments to boost those bodies.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's a dangerous combo-more money than ever, but less oversight. No wonder Renew Europe pushed for budget amendments to boost those bodies.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This dangerous combination prompted Renew Europe (the successor to the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe in the European Parliament) to present amendments to the budget to increase substantially the resources of the EUs audit and control bodies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: If these funds get misused, it could really damage trust in the whole EU project. People won't support more integration if they see corruption.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: If these funds get misused, it could really damage trust in the whole E U project. People won't support more integration if they see corruption.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. After such tough negotiations to get this recovery plan approved, the last thing anyone wants is headlines about fraud instead of green transitions or digital upgrades.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. After such tough negotiations to get this recovery plan approved, the last thing anyone wants is headlines about fraud instead of green transitions or digital upgrades.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After intense negotiations, the EU agreed to issue joint debt for the first time ever to finance the Recovery and Resilience Facility, a common fund that will provide grants and loans to EU member states to green the economy, digitalize our public administrations, and reform the blocs sluggish economies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: They've got the legal framework for transparency, but without proper funding for auditors and prosecutors, it's like having a lock with no key.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They've got the legal framework for transparency, but without proper funding for auditors and prosecutors, it's like having a lock with no key.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Let's hope the member states take those reporting obligations seriously. The success of this entire effort really hinges on it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Let's hope the member states take those reporting obligations seriously. The success of this entire effort really hinges on it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. Europeans are watching closely—they expect accountability, not another cycle of scandals.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. Europeans are watching closely-they expect accountability, not another cycle of scandals.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In short, Europeans expect results, not scandals.

HostA: Yeah, I mean, uh, each staff member now has to monitor 910 million euros worth of spending? Back in 2011 it was only 310 million.
HostB: And their staffing dropped from 470 to 380 employees, even though the budget’s more than doubled. That’s just unsustainable.

HostB: If these funds get misused, it could really damage trust in the whole EU project. People won’t support more integration if they see corruption.

HostB: They’ve got the legal framework for transparency, but without proper funding for auditors and prosecutors, it’s like having a lock with no key.
HostA: Let’s hope the member states take those reporting obligations seriously. The success of this entire effort really hinges on it.
